title: Robert Badinter, who abolished the death penalty in France, has died
summary: The intangible, universal vision of human rights held by the former justice minister permeated his writings and opinions until the end of his life. He died in Paris on February 9, at 95 years of age.

title: White House slams special counsel's report on Biden as politically motivated
summary: Allies of the US president came to his defense on Friday following an investigation that cleared the 81-year-old Democrat of illegally retaining classified documents but damningly branded him as an 'elderly man with a poor memory.'

title: Ukraine's Hungarian minority, caught between defending its identity and fear of Orban's policies
summary: The Hungarian prime minister criticizes Kyiv for not allowing the few thousand Hungarians in Ukraine to express themselves in their language. While few dare to speak out, most do not agree with this allegation which complicates their relationship with Ukraine.

title: Pesticides: 'We, researchers, condemn the way scientific knowledge is being shelved'
summary: In an op-ed for 'Le Monde,' Frencch scientists argue that Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's decision to suspend the Ecophyto plan, announced on February 1, goes against the objective of cutting down on pesticide use.

title: Paris-based Chinese film festival shows banned films
summary: The sixth edition of the event, held in Paris and Lyon, brings together a dozen films that are either banned in China or have limited distributed there.

title: Paris 2024: Thierry Henry faces the conundrum of assembling his Olympic football team roster
summary: With just six months to go before the Olympic Games, the France coach has little certainty over the identity of the players who will make up his squad, in which Antoine Griezmann and Kylian Mbappé are hoping to feature.

title: Gazprombank executives quietly sold their French villas after the Ukraine invasion
summary: Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, properties linked to Russian bank boss Andrey Akimov, his family and associates have been sold. Some were held under dummy corporations and financed from tax havens.

title: Our die-hard obsession with virginity
summary: Le Monde columnist Maïa Mazaurette highlights the fixation on sexual innocence that persists in modern society.

title: In Egypt, Gazans are 'caught between war and a country that doesn't want' them
summary: A few hundred wounded people and their families who have been evacuated from the Gaza Strip are being cared for in Egyptian hospitals but are prevented from moving around the country, which opposes any influx of Gazans despite Israeli bombardment.

title: Biden faces serious doubts about his health nine months before presidential election
summary: The 81-year-old US president's apparent physical frailty, combined with his occasionally confused comments, provides both an angle of attack for Republicans and a source of worry for over two-thirds of Americans.

title: Two killed in Pakistan election protest as Khan allies lead in vote count
summary: Pakistan's former prime minister Nawaz Sharif said he would seek to form a coalition government after his party trailed independent candidates backed by his imprisoned rival, Imran Khan, in parliamentary election results.

title: Jacques Doillon, accused of rape by several actors including Judith Godrèche, denounces the 'lies'
summary: The French director characterized the allegations against him as 'arbitrary denunciations, false accusations and lies.'

title: Reshuffle: Nicole Belloubet, the new Minister for Education and Youth, tackles a school in crisis
summary: The former justice minister replaces Amélie Oudéa-Castéra in a difficult context, with marked opposition from the teaching community to the reforms launched by Gabriel Attal.

title: French prosecutors seek trial for Lafarge cement group over terror financing
summary: The company paid nearly €13 million to middlemen to keep its Syrian cement factory running in 2013 and 2014, after other French firms had pulled out of the country.

title: Iran's Ayatollah Ali Khamenei removed from Instagram and Facebook
summary: Meta said the country's Supreme Leader's accounts were deleted for 'repeatedly violating our Dangerous Organizations and Individuals policy'.

title: Prince Harry settles phone hacking lawsuit against UK tabloid
summary: The Duke of Sussex settled his case against Mirror Group Newspapers, but said he will continue his legal battle against the publishers of the Daily Mail and The Sun.

title: Vladimir Putin tells Tucker Carlson that Russia cannot be defeated in Ukraine
summary: In a publicity exercise conducted with the conservative American presenter, the Russian president also said he ruled out the idea of invading Poland or Latvia.

title: European countries are turning to 'selective immigration' to mend labor shortages
summary: Under pressure from various business sectors, governments of all political leanings have amended legislation to make up for shortages in the labor force.

title: Senegal: Student killed in protest against election postponement
summary: Anger has mounted since President Macky Sall postponed a presidential election scheduled for February 25 until December.

title: 'The explosion in AI-related electricity demand has already had local consequences'
summary: Given artificial intelligence's high energy consumption, it might be prudent to focus on developing smaller, more specialized AI models tailored to specific needs, argues journalist Alexandre Piquard.

title: Drug use soars in Turkey
summary: Turkey has long been known as a transit country for narcotics, but recent statistics indicate a growing presence of methamphetamine in society. The government is beginning to recognize the problem and is stepping up operations against drug gangs.
